Context:
The George Brown College Centre for Business offers a program in Business Administration – Accounting (B107), which includes studies in auditing, corporate taxation, law, and strategic management. This program enables students to build proficiency in using spreadsheets, databases, and accounting software programs, as well as developing essential communication skills. Students will learn to perform accounting transactions according to International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).

This Centre for Business program is part of George Brown College's School of Accounting and Finance. The college has earned international recognition from the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP), with 14 accredited diplomas, advanced diplomas, and degree programs.

George Brown College students in the Centre for Business program are required to bring their own laptops due to its Bring Your Own Device initiative. For more information, contact the Centre for Business at business@georgebrown.ca.

Career opportunities for graduates include positions such as audit associate, accounting analyst, accounts payable or receivables clerk, junior accountant, and financial analyst in various industries. Graduates may be eligible for advanced standing in the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program. For more information on future study options, see the transfer guide.

Graduates with a minimum Program GPA of 3.0 from the Advanced Accounting Diploma (B107/B157) may apply for degree transfer options.

The program does not include work experience. Students seeking to apply with work experience should apply to B157 instead.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business Administration – Accounting Program B107 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Diploma graduates with a minimum Program GPA of 3.0 from B107 or B157 programs may be eligible to transfer into Semester 5 of the Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) with a specialization in Accounting (B322). The maximum number of credits that can be transferred is 25. Interested graduates who do not meet the GPA standard for transfer are encouraged to upgrade.

Contact information:
- Katherine Friesen (transfer process): kfriesen@georgebrown.ca
- Mohammad Khan (program content, CPA qualifications and career advancement): Mohammad.Khan@georgebrown.ca

Graduates of the program might wish to pursue professional designations/certifications from Chartered Professional Accountants of Ontario or Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA).

Exemptions for ACCA designation:
- Foundations in Accountancy (FIA) Qualification
- Business and Technology (BT)
- Management Accounting (MA)
- Financial Accounting (FA)
- Corporate and Business Law (LW) - All foundation papers

Additional information can be found on the ACCA website.

Transfer opportunities for three-year Accounting diploma students to enter the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program through an articulation agreement.

To graduate from B107, you need to complete 34 courses: 29 Mandatory courses, 2 Business Electives and 3 General Education Electives. The specific requirements for designations/certifications are set by the granting bodies and not George Brown College. For more information on designation/certification requirements, visit the respective websites.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business Administration – Accounting Program B107 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
To graduate from the college, students are required to complete 34 courses in total. Three of these courses must be General Education Electives chosen from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI).

Students may be required to take certain prerequisite courses before progressing to others, such as COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation). These courses do not count towards the 34 courses required for graduation and students will be charged extra for them.

Students must make up any failed or dropped courses before being eligible to graduate. Some making-up courses can be taken during the day, while others are offered in the evening through Continuing Education. Students should check with the business office staff to ensure that continuing education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program and to inquire about any special timetable requirements they may have. Some courses may not be offered in every semester.

The curriculum planner for academic year 2023-2024 includes the following courses for Semesters 1 and 2:

Semester 1:
- ACCT 1001: Accounting Fundamentals I (no prerequisite)
- BUS 1038: Business Concepts I (no prerequisite)
- ECON 1031: Microeconomics (no prerequisite)
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts (no prerequisite)
- CMMK 1087: Human Skills (no prerequisite)
- MATH 1191: Mathematics of Finance (no prerequisite)

Semester 2:
- ACCT 1012: Accounting Fundamentals II (ACCT 1001 prerequisite)
- COMP 1010: Business Computer Applications I (no prerequisite)
- COMM 1034: Professional Communications I (COMM 2000 prerequisite)
- ECON 1032: Macroeconomics (no prerequisite)
- PSY 1129: Organizational Behaviour (no prerequisite)

Additional courses for Semester 3 are listed in the text, including ACCT 2001, ACCT 2011, ACCT 2012, and STAT 1010. These courses have prerequisites of ACCT 1012 and MATH 1191, respectively.

Context:
Program Offered: The George Brown College offers the following courses and programs: Environmental Economics (ECON 1031 or ECON 1032 or ECON 1034), Retirement Planning (FIN 1011), Talking Business (COMM 1034), Business Research & Report Writing (COMM 1034), Marketing (MARK 2053), Negotiation Skills, Detailed course outlines, and an Articulation Agreement.

Program Learning Outcomes: The graduate of the program is able to record financial transactions in compliance with Canadian Generally Accepted Accounting Principles for various types of organizations, prepare and present financial statements, reports and other documents, contribute to strategic decision-making by applying advanced management accounting concepts, prepare income tax returns, analyze and evaluate organizational structures and the interdependence of functional areas, analyze and evaluate the impact of economic variables, legislation, ethics, technological advances and the environment on an organization’s operations, analyze and evaluate an organization's internal control system, and coordinate team projects by applying project management principles.

Tuition & Fees: Domestic Tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022 is $4,500.00. International Tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 is $17,455.00. The text mentions that fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates.

The college has agreements with several universities in Canada, the United States, and abroad, which may give students credit for their college diploma.

No specific information about the college name or contact details is mentioned in the text.

Context:
* International students should visit the "International Fees and Related Costs" page for more information on fees.
* Financial assistance is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria.
* Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, with a grade 12 English (C or U) and either a grade 11 math (C, M or U) or a grade 12 math (C or U). Mature students can take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade to get the necessary credits.
* Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions.
* English proficiency is required for success in the program; applicants might need to complete English testing to demonstrate proficiency.
* International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
* Information sessions are held on a regular basis. Domestic students can apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students and those with queries about domestic admission requirements can contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit their website.

Context:
The Admissions Office can be contacted at admissions@georgebrown.ca or by visiting the Admissions section of the website. International student inquiries should contact one of the international recruitment representatives, who specialize by country of origin, via booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page. The Financial Aid Office can be contacted at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or by visiting the Financial Aid section for inquiries about OSAP, bursaries, scholarships, and other financial matters. To make an appointment with an Entry Advisor for advice on program options, please review the frequently asked questions first.

The Centre for Business can be contacted at business@georgebrown.ca or by phone at (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. The Business Administration: Accounting program is offered out of the School of Accounting and Finance, with classes taking place primarily at the St. James Campus, located at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Campus tours can be arranged by signing up for a campus tour today or checking out the virtual tour. The Centre for Business can also be followed on Instagram and LinkedIn.

Program-specific inquiries related to the Business Administration: Accounting program should be directed to Francis Taylor (Francis.Taylor@georgebrown.ca) or Kelly Jung (Kelly.Jung@georgebrown.ca). International students are encouraged to contact the relevant international recruitment representative for their country of origin.

Email addresses: admissions@georgebrown.ca, FinAid@georgebrown.ca, business@georgebrown.ca, Francis.Taylor@georgebrown.ca, Kelly.Jung@georgebrown.ca
Phone number: (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160
Campus locations: St. James Campus, 200 King St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada; and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
